clinical_summary: On 2025-05-01 laboratory testing showed a C-reactive protein of 1.8 mg/dL (within reference range), procalcitonin of 0.13 ng/mL (low risk for sepsis), total bilirubin 1.4 mg/dL (reference 0.2-1.0) with direct bilirubin 0.6 mg/dL (reference 0.0-0.2) and indirect bilirubin 0.8 mg/dL (reference 0.2-0.8), normal alanine aminotransferase (10 U/L) and aspartate aminotransferase (12 U/L), white blood cell count 7500 cells/ÂµL with neutrophils 58%, and a normal peripheral smear.

differential_diagnoses.name: Gilbert syndrome
differential_diagnoses.justification: Mild isolated elevation of indirect bilirubin (0.8 mg/dL at upper limit) with normal liver enzymes and normal hemoglobin parameters suggests a benign unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia.

differential_diagnoses.name: Mild hepatocellular dysfunction
differential_diagnoses.justification: Slightly elevated total and direct bilirubin despite normal ALT and AST may indicate early or mild liver conjugation impairment.

differential_diagnoses.name: Hemolysis
differential_diagnoses.justification: Elevated indirect bilirubin could result from increased red cell breakdown, though no anemia or reticulocyte data are provided.

differential_diagnoses.name: Early sepsis or systemic infection
differential_diagnoses.justification: CRP is modestly elevated and a sepsis risk score of 6.5 is noted, but low procalcitonin and normal WBC make infection unlikely.
